It’s not clear how many minds Sen. Bernie Sanders changed on Monday or if he picked up a single vote speaking at Liberty University. But garnering voters wasn’t the point of his visit, and the senator’s willingness to take his message to a bastion of conservatism underscores why his long-shot campaign has gained “Bernmentum” and is now leading former Secretary of StateÂ Hillary ClintonÂ in Iowa and New Hampshire among Democrats.
Liberty, which bills itself as the worldâs largest Christian university and whose slogan is âTraining Champions for Christ,âÂ is pretty much a required stop for Republican presidential candidates. Jeb Bush delivered the commencement address in May.
When Sen. SandersÂ of Vermont–the least religious state in the U.S.–spoke there on Monday, a few of his supporters were in attendance, but most of the thousands who packed into the basketball auditorium were students.
There were no protests.Â Sen. Sanders received a respectful, even warm, welcome.
The candidate began by emphasizing his support for gay rights and said he is pro-choice. Then he said: âI believe from the bottom of my heart that it is vitally important for those of us who hold different views to be able to engage in a civil discourse.â
And so an avowed socialist and liberal candidate for president went to one of the most conservative places in the country to share his message.
His appearance at Liberty was bracketed by campaign rallies in North Carolina and Virginia, and his pointÂ about wealth and income inequality was the same in all three places. âWhen we talk about morality and justice we have to understand that there is no justice when so few have so much and so many have so little.â
He urged the students to âhave the courage to stand with the poor and working people and â¦ to take on the powerful and wealthy who are hurting this country.â
Student body President Quincy Thompson, a senior majoring in pastoral leadership, told me that all the students he spoke with about Sen. Sanders’s appearance were âexcited to have him and hear a different perspective. . . . It woke a lot of students up to the severity of the poverty that is here in the United States.”
Sen. Sanders was positive and respectful without giving ground on issues that matter most to him. He was the same person who has been traveling the country talking about income inequality for months.
“It is easy to go out and talk to people who agree with you,” he said Monday. Itâs harder, but more important, to try to find common ground with people with whom you disagree. The popularity of “outsider” candidates so far in the 2016 presidential campaign suggests that voters would like to see more of this in our politics.
